The private placement and FX on existing bonds, along with the GBP 80 million decrease in cash resulted in net
debt of GBP 732 million, up from GBP 560 million at the year-end. This gives leverage of 4.7x last 12 months adjusted EBITDA, removing the write-off
relating to the sale of legacy IP leverage from 4 to 4.2x. And of course, including a pro forma look at the first-time adoption of lease liabilities for
IFRS 16 of GBP 112 million, net debt at the period on a pro forma basis would have been GBP 844 million.

Uh, yeah, so 4.7x.

1966AndAllThat Jeremy Clarkson pointed out the problem with Ford is that if your parents had one you would aspire to a German luxury brand even though Ford's have brilliant affordable engineering.

PostmanPat @BE: an absolute gem!!
11:15 am
BE11:15am

Let's check if Goldman's updated that £20.20 price target. Oh, it has, this morning in fact.

GBKrona @FATDAZ - totally agree with you - much bigger market than 35k
BE11:15am

Aston Martin reported 1H adj. EBITDA of £22 mn (GSe £51 mn) on revenues of £407 mn (GSe £419 mn) leading to a margin of 5.4% (GSe 12.2%). £19 mn of the adj. EBITDA shortfall to our numbers was due to provisioning, as highlighted in last week’s profit warning. However, gross margins were also 3.4% lower than we had anticipated (36.3% vs. GSe 39.7% and 1H18 42.5%) on a 2.9% top-line miss. More importantly, Aston Martin’s cash finished the quarter at £127 mn, as negative free cash flow of -£161 mn was £96 mn worse than we had expected. In its press release, AM commented that the company has “flexibility within [its] existing debt financing arrangements which have no maintenance covenants”. In light of results, we place our estimates and price target under review.

BE11:16am

Cash is primary concern at this point - AM’s £96 mn weaker than expected FCF was largely accounted for by weaker WC (£48mn), lower EBITDA and higher interest expenses. Investments during 1H of £159 mn were broadly in line with our expectations (£156 mn). The negative cash development is largely explained by an increase in inventories of £77 mn vs. the start of the year with 1H inventories sitting at £242 mn (see section below for more thoughts). As a result, reported net leverage stood at 4.7x trailing 12-month EBITDA (vs. 2.3x at YE2018). Leverage would look higher if EBITDA were adjusted for R&D capitalization.

Irish HF guy Tesla to buy Aston Martin.. fantasy M&A
GBKrona @BE - perhaps GS should sell puts to their Target Prices. I would be a heavy subscriber.
FATDAZ @GBK just checked range rover sales in march 2019 they sold 9,400 velars in that month alone and 10,500 sports on top of that
Flaneur Aston have little to offer any buyer other than the name, especially in this transition phase to electric. Loads of these companies are done for.
Nately Be interested to know who bought into that AML float, and with whose money.
11:17 am
BE11:18am

Who could've anticipated that a company with a second-rate brand, a very lumpy sales history and a tendency to blow out to 5x ND/ebitda would fail to deliver after a flotation designed to give its main holders an exit? It's totally sideswiped me ......

BE11:18am

Weaker gross margins, lower sales, inventory build - All of the factors contributing to AM’s weaker-than-expected performance, from our perspective, have the same fundamental root cause. Demand, at today’s price levels, for AM’s products is lower than expected. We look for management to provide commentary on: a/ which vehicle lines are underperforming, b/ what the root cause of that underperformance is, c/ what levers, if any, AM has to address the underperformance and d/ why the underperformance should not present a concern for DBX volume aspirations in 2020/21.

FATDAZ @GBK @BE didnt they do something like for themselves with CDOs back in early 2000's
BE11:18am

As we wrote following the profit warning last week, Aston Martin is a medium-term story and its future is unlikely to be defined by 2019’s performance. Nevertheless, concerns around cash are now front and centre for this year (AM’s cash balance at the end of 1H of £127 mn looks low compared to a trade payables of £719 mn - even taking into account that a large proportion of this may be customer deposits) coupled with potential operating risk (not just in the plants but in the sales and distribution network) as well as questions on Aston’s ability to sustain volumes on vehicles that are more than 12 months old.
Inventory build needs further clarity - AM commented that the build in inventories was in preparation for wholesale deliveries weighted towards 2H, with many finished vehicles sitting at the plant and awaiting dealer delivery. We note that in absolute terms inventories at this point are £72 mn higher than at the end of 1H 2018. Meanwhile, from a wholesale perspective, 2H this year does not look like it will be stronger than 2H last year: AM sold 4.1k units in 2H last year vs. an implied 4.0k for 2H 2019 at the mid-point of the revised guidance. Hence, it seems a YoY increase is more a function of over build in 1H (7k units p.a. run-rate) which would have to be compensated by lower build sequentially and presumably YoY in 2H.

Soundbuy Just need one of those ejector seats to malfunction and, well..........

Irish HF guy Intu forget to accrue £8m CT for non payment of distributable income due to dividend being cut, in the H1 figures, rents down 7.7%, expenses attributable to rental income over 20%, what a mess. mind you, at some share price, it is a buy, £0.30p, its trading at 52p

Hence we retain a positive stance albeit cognisant that the risk profile (and reward) has ratcheted up somewhat of late.

BE11:26am

Intu releases its 19H1 results this morning suggesting things had got worse still since the 19Q1 update and that there would be no overnight fixes. On the portfolio itself values were down another -9.6% l-f-l in the six months (vs -9.1% for Hammerson’s UK portfolio and -4.4% overall). This was driven by a further +23bps yield expansion and -4.1% drop in ERVs, again targeting particularly the larger units which have suffered more from tenant failures. This led to another -20% drop in EPRA NAV/share to 233p which is already below our 12/19E 270p, and highlights just how severe things have become. This drop in values pushes the LTV to a 57.6% (53% at 12/18A) with the Trafford Centre refinancing still to come (adding potentially another c.3% to this figure).

Irish HF guy @BE so true. Current yield on the portfolio is approx 6.5% based on net rental income, debt levels and current share price!
BE11:27am

Operationally, Intu cut l-f-l NRI guidance to -4 to -6% for 2019 (from -1 to
-2%) at the 19Q1 results to include the impact of CVAs/Administrations,
however as guided by management this morning, the outlook appears even tougher and as such l-f-l net rental income was down -7.7%. Much of this is due to a space take-up being much lower than expected. 109 leases
were signed (£14m of annualized rent) broadly in line with ERVs and +2%
ahead of passing (net effective) rent. 101 lease renewals were conducted
at +7% releasing spreads. Footfall was surprisingly up +0.8% (UK +0.4%
and Spain +3.5%). Occupancy dropped again, now down to 95.1% from
96.7% at 12/18A. Unsurprisingly this translated into a fairly dismal EPRA
EPS of 2.7p vs 8.6p last year which again is even below the run rate for
our 12/19E target of 11.6p - which already included £300m of disposals this
year (and a similar amount next year). Part of Derby was sold for £108.7m
during the half but discussions are still ongoing for Spanish portfolio.

Nately Thanks @Irish.Got to love INTU considering raising money now, when s/p at all time low. What happens if Whittaker not on board?
11:27 am
BE11:27am

With the share price now down to 70p the stock is once again trading at
a 70% discount to reported EPRA NAV, but which can close rapidly with
falls like this. Similarly what appeared to be a double digit earnings yield
now contracts down to a 7.7% EPS yield based on today’s numbers, and a
reminder that there is no 2019 dividend. Therefore despite where the stock now trades we are still not brave enough to step in. SELL.

BE11:28am

Today’s results highlight the issues facing Intu, with the H1 NAV
down 19%, EPS down 33% and LTV increasing to 58%. With
the shares trading on a c70% NAV discount, investors need to
weigh up the large discount and the balance sheet risk against
the likelihood of the company being taken private, which we
believe would be in everyone’s interests if willing partners can be
found. We retain our Hold recommendation and place our target
price under review.

Irish HF guy @GBK, Hammerson down in sympathy, but the premium outlets and France are 44% of gross portfolio and debt levels are much lower, 36% equity to total assets ratio compared to 13% in INTU
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Conclusion: NAV collapsed -19% to 252p (-31% over 12mths) with valuations cut -9.6% (UK 10.4%, Spain flat) as ERVs declined -4.1% and +23% bps of yield shift to NIY 5.21%. LfL rents were -7.7% as EPS declined 33% with additional drivers higher finance costs and £9m of tax due to non-payment of the compulsory PID dividends for REITs with no divi planned "for the time being." LTV increased to 58.5% (FY18 53.1%, target 50% or less) and intu Derby (£109m net proceeds) completed post period
meant this declined 90bps to 57.6% with Kd unch at 4.3%.
Detail: The short term +ve is that there has been good progress on disposal of the Spanish centres however INTU will lose a growth driver give their stronger medium term prospects. Collectively their value is £613m, however, with secured debt at c. 50% LTV, equity from the sale would do little to dent the £4.9bn net debt pile. Security of the income stream continues to be hampered by CVAs whilst the av. lease length reduced to 6.5yrs from 7.2yrs.

marktime Someone overseas with cojones will be snapping these property trusts up
Excel Developer Fed this evening, BofE tomorrow. Carney can't say anymore base case of smooth Brexit, he must change tone.
FATDAZ @Marktime someone like Simon in the US or a SWF from Mideast or Asia?
GBKrona @Irish - agree - HMSO a screaming buy if No Deal Brexit is thwarted. Lets just hope that HMSO don;t suddenly pursue INTU again ...

And Caz, off the conference call.

BE11:35am

Challenges being faced are well known and something wider sector is
experiencing however Intu is confident it can deliver on its new strategy.
5 year strategy that will reshape and rebuild.
 First day as CEO, Matthew Roberts told employees to (1) act faster
given the pace of change is accelerating, (2) be bold – take the braver
choice if decision is between two and (3) look after mental well-being.

Irish HF guy @marktime, agreed, but cost of debt is much higher for the UK REIT's compared with Euro comparables.
11:35 am
BE11:35am

Admirable.

BE11:35am

New CFO: “what a challenge”. It’s a tough market and it’s going to be
challenging. Operationally however, it’s been better than they were
expecting. Financially, it’s unquestionably challenging. Focusing on
lowering leverage and the CFO added that they have 12 months to get
ahead of this before refinancing starts to look more pressing.
 On CVAs “hope the worst is behind us,” but a contrast in approaches
by Intu: Debenhams CVA plan seemed well planned in Intu’s view but
compared to Arcadia, Intu didn’t think the turnaround plan was
compelling and couldn’t understand rationale of store classification.
Where there was no change in requested rent (9), lease expiries and
break clause were coming up over the next 12 months. However, where
rent reductions were sought (17), lease lengths were notably longer. Intu
voted against the Arcadia CVA.

Punter @Marktime/Fatdaz etc, yes but probably want more comfort on not getting a Corbynista regime
FATDAZ @punter good point re Corbyn
BE11:37am

 On timelines, Intu flags fixing the balance sheet running until 2021,
simplifying the efficiencies to 2020, sharpening customer focus to 2022
and transforming centres to 2023. At end of 5 years, Intu aims to own 10
of top 20 centres with each centre over 20m visits p.a.
 Not ruling out an equity raising at some stage. The group stresses the
need to fix balance sheet, if it doesn’t manage to do this then everything
else is ‘irrelevant’. Before they raise equity the group is not paying
divided (c. £100m savings p.a.), cutting costs and selling assets.
Management is aware that raising equity below nominal value would
need a shareholder vote. On Trafford, there has been a delay in the
refinancing as the group has wider balance sheet discussions. If the group
can get refinancing done by end 2020 then still have all of 2021 to get a
disposal done. Management stressed that self-help was priority for
example; selling Spain assets could generated £250-300m of net cash.
 CVAs big impact in 2019, rate of decline in 2020 will moderate. Top
20 tenants, 4 have gone through CVA in last 12 months. The other 16 are
well capitalized global brands.

NIM deteriorating, NII down 3% year on year. Outlook has the usual macro caution. It's ...... well, it's like all other banks to report recently. See CYBG yesterday, the Irish ones earlier in the week.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Have Barclays.

BE11:45am

Stat PBT of £1,294m is 26% light vs. consensus driven by a £550m PPI provision that wasn’t in Street numbers. On an underlying basis, underlying PBT of £2,026m is 1% light vs. consensus driven by costs 1% heavy (driven by higher remediation costs) with income/impairments broadly in line. Within revenues however, net interest income is 2% light with the Q2 net interest margin of 2.89% a 1bp miss and down 1bp q/q, and this is offset by better other income which is 5% ahead (driven by strong Insurance performance). Within costs, underlying operating expenses (i.e. ex remediation ) are 2% better than consensus, down 3% y/y. 1H19 interim dividend of 1.12p 2% light of consensus (1.14p). The CET1 ratio of 13.9% is 30bp light vs. Street (impacted by 33bp PPI) and is flat q/q. TNAV of 53.0p is in-line but down 1% q/q. Guidance remains broadly unchanged – most notably Lloyds expecting c.290bp FY19 NIM, although given the PPI charge, they expect 12% statutory RoTE in 2019 (down from 14-15%) with capital generation now expected at bottom end of 170-200bp range for the year.

GBKrona @Irish - BoI NIM's nowhere near Lloyds though

Davy:

BE11:47am

PPI remains the gift that keeps taking away and will result in
capital generation being at the lower end of Lloyds Banking
Group’s (LLOY) guided range in 2019; however, with a robust
capital position, this should not impact materially on the capital
return story. Elsewhere, expect significant focus on the margin
outlook beyond 2019 with commentary around “resilient through
the plan period” no longer appearing in its outlook statement.

marktime Its like those Royal Marines marches imagine getting to 29 Aug and being told PPI extension another year due tp enquiry volumes

Irish HF guy LLoyds, £650m PPI provision for H1 2109.
11:49 am
BE11:49am

And one of those walls of text from Morgan Stanley.

BE11:49am

Lloyds Ppop was inline with expectations and NIM guidance of c.2.90% is re-affirmed; however, resilience is driven by the structural hedge which could see pressure in 2020 if flat yield curves remain. We lower our earnings 1% and reduce our buyback to £2bn post PPI top up. We remain Overweight. An inline PPOP result, underscores Lloyds earnings resilience. Headline revenues of £4.7bn were inline with consensus as weaker NII (2% lower vs. consensus) was offset by insurance driving a 5% other income beat. 2% lower operating costs drove a 1% better underlying Ppop vs. consensus. Lloyds took a £550mn PPI top up and as a result, FY statutory ROTE guidance has been reduced to c.12% (vs. 14-15% previously), while organic capital generation will be at the lower end of the 170-200bps level. TNAV was at 53p inline.NIM was down 2bp to 2.89% in Q2 and c.2.90% FY guidance maintained. NIM ticked down 2bps to 2.89%, just a touch below consensus. Margin is proving more resilient due to the lower redemptions in the mortgage book and less roll overs in the structural hedge then peers as we argued in our upgrade note earlier this year (UK Banks: NII headwinds building, switch into Lloyds from RBS (11 Feb 2019)). However underline loan spreads remain under pressure and the key focus will be on the sustainability of structural hedge income if rates continue lower though-out 2020/2021. Lloyds continues to deliver ahead of expectations on costs. We lower our costs by 1.5% in 2020E to reflect the good performance so far this year, and we expect cost income ratio to improve both this year and next to 47% in 2020E. This compares to management's target of low 40s exiting 2020E and reflects our lower revenues assumptions. CET1 of 14%, 20bp below consensus due to PPI top up. The higher than expected PPI top up accounted for 28bps of CET1 drag in Q2 and as a result, management now expect FY19 organic capital generation will be at the lower end of the 170-200bps range. We estimate a CET1 of 13.7% by year end, which includes a total £850mn PPI charge for the full year and we lower our buyback to £2bn vs. £2.5bn previously (consensus £1.8bn).We reiterate our Overweight on the stock. Underlying market conditions continue to be challenging; however, room to cut costs and longer duration of the balance sheet will drive more resilient earnings than peers. We reiterate our Overweight on the stock which trades on 1x TBV for a 13% ROTE in 2020E, and an 11% total yield this year and next. We reduce our PT to 68p from 70p inline with our earnings cut.

BE11:57am

Profits fell by 45%, which was as expected given the low death
rate in H1 and reduction in pricing. So the key news is that the
company has chosen to remove the dividend ‘in order to
maintain maximum flexibility and liquidity during the
transformation’ – we see this as a sensible move given the CMA
enquiry, but clearly shows the potential pressure on long-term
cash generation and focus on covenants.
Funeral numbers fell by 9% in H1, with LFL market share
11.8% vs 12% last year (when share had improved). Pricing was
£2919 vs £3023 in the prior period – this is in line with the
company’s FY target of £2940. We are not making any changes
to our full-year forecasts, albeit the death rate needs to be higher
in H2 (which should happen given the H1 trends). We continue
to see considerable risk on pricing given the CMA enquiry.

BE11:59am

The company has been clear that this is intended to be temporary. We are
expecting FCF to be c£10m in the current year and removing the dividend will save £12m, hence enabling a reduction in debt.
The decision to suspend dividends also reflects the Restricted Payment
Condition, which has a covenant of 1.4x debt service to FCF. At June 2019 this ratio was 1.53x, so still meeting the covenant but close enough to merit serious attention. If the RPC was not achieved, the company’s ability to pay dividends could have been impacted.
The primary covenant for the bonds is for EBITDA to total debt service to be 1.5x – on this covenant, the headroom continues to be comfortable with the ratio at 2.08x at June 2019.

BE12:00pm

Trading performance
H1 PBT fell 45% to £23.9m, which was in line with our forecast of £24m.
Profits in Funeral Services fell by £11.6m. The key drivers to performance were a £7.0m reduction due to lower deaths, £4.4m due to pricing and £2.0m due to market share reduction, partially offset by £1.8m benefit from cost reduction and acquisitions.
Profits in Crematoria fell by £2.6m to £20.8m. The key drivers were a £2.4m reduction due to lower deaths, £0.6m due to lower average income, £0.5m from higher costs partially offset by £0.8m benefit from market share gains.
Central costs increased by £2.7m to £14.6m as the company invested in central services and particularly digital capabilities.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

W e see the decision to suspend the dividend as a precaution against a materially unfavourable CMA review and/or a further significant intensification of the competitive environment in the funeral industry. In our view it is not because there is any danger of DTY breaching any of its covenants in the current industry
environment. At the H119 stage, including H119 results that were adversely affected by a lower UK death rate, DTY was still comfortably within its various covenants. We would also note that net debt fell by £10m in the period, that DTY had cash balances of £49.8m at the end of the period, and that DTY has access to a £50m RCF.
 In our view, the extent of the negative share price reaction will depend on whether, and to what extent, the suspension of the dividend is interpreted as signaling more nervousness about the outlook. In our view DTY’s management has been very candid about the uncertain outlook for some considerable time. There is no change to their view. Although DTY’s H119 profits are well down, due to the 7% fall in the UK death rate, there is no change to its FY19 assumptions or guidance. In fact, progress on both market share and pricing is encouraging.

Bluesky21 Or do people always use the same funeral service provider for both parents?
BE12:02pm

We would also argue that DTY has, for some time, been a recovery stock rather than an income stock, as reflected in the changing shareholder base. This should mitigate the negative impact of the dividend suspension.
 W e retain our assumption of a 3% fall in UK deaths for 2019. We estimate that deaths in the balance of the year (from mid-July, the latest period for which data is available) would have to be +2% to deliver this. Given the 7% fall in H119 we see this as a very reasonable assumption, based on the tendency of death rates to even out over whole years. Our financial forecasts remain unchanged, other than for the dividend.

BE12:06pm

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: Umicore reported H1 2019 EBIT (including JV's) of €240m, down 8% y/y and 2%
above consensus (€235m). This was on the back of sales (excl. metal) of €1,634m,
down 3% y/y and 1% below cons (€1,655m). The beat to consensus at the EBIT line
reflects better than expected EBIT in Catalysis (+5%) and Recycling (+10%), whereas
the battery materials-containing Energy & Surface Technology (E&ST) division was 4%
light. Recurring EPS came in at €0.62/share, down 8% y/y and 1% below cons (€0.63).
FCF in 1H19 was €11m (vs -€164m in 1H18), this was due to an inflow of working
capital (€10m vs -€335m in 1H18) offset by higher capex (€235m vs €196m). The
interim DPS of €0.375/share was in line with consensus.
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: E&ST reported 1H19 EBIT of €102m, down 16% y/y and 4% below consensus
(€106m), reflecting the impact of lower volumes of NMC and falling cobalt prices.
Catalysis delivered 1H19 EBIT of €87m, flat y/y and 5% ahead of consensus (€83m),
helped by strong demand in Precious Metal Chemistry and volume growth in gasoline
autocats despite the decline in auto production. Recycling 1H19 EBIT came in at €76m
(vs consensus of €69m), down 4% y/y, helped by the improvement in metal prices.

BE12:06pm

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
No. After the cut to EBIT guidance for 2019 in April (see here) management has
reiterated the EBIT range of €475-525m based primarily on a more favourable metal
mix in Recycling. This compares with consensus EBIT of €490m and UBS at €461m. To
hit 2019 consensus EBIT, 2H19 EBIT would need to be flat on last year (€252m). In our
opinion, this is not a given with the continuing headwinds that Umicore faces in autos
in 2H19, particularly in E&ST. Metal price benefits in Recycling could also reverse. We
expect FCF to be negative in 2H19 as the new NMC plant in China is ramped up.
Valuation: How would we expect investors to react?
A: We believe the shares will react positively to the positive FCF and EBIT beat vs
consensus. We continue to argue m-term overcapacity in the cathode materials
business (see here), allied to slow growth in Catalysis. At our PT (€23) the shares would
be trading on 10.9x 2019E EV/EBITDA and 18.7x 2019E EPS.

1H adj EBIT of €240m (-8% YoY) is 5%2% ahead of JPMe consensus. The beat vs. consensus was within the
Catalysis and Recycling divisions, with Energy and Surface tech coming 4.4% below cons but 9% ahead of JPMe.
1H19 FCF of -€43.4m was almost in line with our estimate though improved significantly vs. -€211m in 1H18 as
after two years of significant working capital related cash-out, 1H19 saw a broadly stable working capital.
ND/EBITDA at end of 1H19 was ~1.4x. Company has reiterated FY19 adj EBIT guidance of €475-525m with
consensus currently at €490m. Further, the company is also expecting a substantial improvement in FCF also in 2H19
(JPMe: -€87m) vs. 2H18 (-€366m) with working capital expected to be flat also in 2H. Given a high level of
bearishness on the stock, we believe these results should bring some relief to the stock today. We also note
incrementally improved disclosures by the company in 1H19 which is very welcome.

BE12:08pm

Adj EBIT in Energy & Surface Technologies in 1H19 of €101.6m/16.7% margin was down 16% YoY reflecting the
impact of the previously flagged slowdown in the EV demand (EV related sales flat in 1H), almost no demand for
energy storage applications in Korea, the direct and indirect impact of lower cobalt prices and higher D&A. 1H EBIT
in the Catalysis division of €86.6m/12.1% margin was flat YoY and ~5% higher than expectations despite the weak
auto demand environment and diesel share decline in Europe. This reflects company’s stronger position in the
gasoline market (disclosed to be 86% of Umicore’s light duty volumes in 1H19) as well as share gain in China.
Recycling adj EBIT of €76.6m/24.4% was down 4% YoY but 1%/10% higher than JPMe/cons with lower volumes
due to maintenance shutdown in 1H offset partially by better mix and higher metal prices, on average.

A 50bp cut is possible, but not probable as recently stronger activity and inflation data together with the implications of recent Fed communication all point toward a smaller, 25bp cut. An early end of balance sheet reduction will likely be
